examples: I think he is very nice.
I met him recently.
Is this his dog?
He told me that the house is his.
He said he would rather do it himself.
He is really beautiful.
He answered the phone.
He takes good care of his cat.
He did it all by himself.
He talks in his sleep.
He landed the plane safely.
He argues that…
Did you buy him his gift?
I asked him if I can borrow his pencil.
I talked to him yesterday.
Would you like to go to the movies with him?
Can you call him when his cat awakes?
His graduation starts soon.
My favorite color is purple, his is yellow.
he.name: he/him

examples: I think she is very nice.
I met her recently.
Is this her dog?
She told me that the house is hers.
She said she would rather do it herself.
She is really beautiful.
She answered the phone.
She takes good care of her cat.
She did it all by herself.
She talks in her sleep.
She landed the plane safely.
She argues that…
Did you buy her her gift?
I asked her if I can borrow her pencil.

Can you call her when her cat awakes?
Her graduation starts soon.
My favorite color is purple, hers is yellow.
she.name: she/her

they.history: Singular “they” has been used in English to describe an unspecified person {https://www.academicwritingsuccess.com/the-astonishing-history-of-singular-they/=since the late 1300s} (it's even older than singular “you”!). Nowadays, it's the most popular choice among people who prefer gender neutral forms. It starts being {https://www.merriam-webster.com/words-at-play/singular-nonbinary-they=accepted by dictionaries} too.@It is also common to use {/they/them/themself=“themself”} as a reflexive form.
they.sourcesInfo: This list of sources includes both the version with {/they=“themselves”} and {/they/them/themselves=“themself”}, as well as those that don't happen to use reflexive.
examples: I think they are very nice.
I met them recently.
Is this their dog?
They told me that the house is theirs.
They said they would rather do it themselves.
They are really beautiful.
They answered the phone.
They take good care of their cat.
They did it all by themselves.
They talk in their sleep.
They landed the plane safely.
They argue that…
Did you buy them their gift?
I asked them if I can borrow their pencil.
I talked to them yesterday.
Would you like to go to the movies with them?
Can you call them when their cat awakes?
Their graduation starts soon.
My favorite color is purple, theirs is yellow.
they.name: they/them

they/them/themself.history: Singular “they” has been used in English to describe an unspecified person {https://www.academicwritingsuccess.com/the-astonishing-history-of-singular-they/=since the late 1300s} (it's even older than singular “you”!). Nowadays, it's the most popular choice among people who prefer gender neutral forms. It starts being {https://www.merriam-webster.com/words-at-play/singular-nonbinary-they=accepted by dictionaries} too.@It is also common to use {/they=“themselves”} as a reflexive form.
they/them/themself.sourcesInfo: This list of sources includes both the version with {/they=“themselves”} and {/they/them/themselves=“themself”}, as well as those that don't happen to use reflexive.
examples: I think they are very nice.
I met them recently.
Is this their dog?
They told me that the house is theirs.
They said they would rather do it themself.
They are really beautiful.
They answered the phone.
They take good care of their cat.
They did it all by themself.
They talk in their sleep.
They landed the plane safely.
They argue that…
Did you buy them their gift?
I asked them if I can borrow their pencil.
I talked to them yesterday.
Would you like to go to the movies with them?
Can you call them when their cat awakes?
Their graduation starts soon.
My favorite color is purple, theirs is yellow.
they/them/themself.name: they/them

it.history: Although “it” is normally used for objects, not people, some actually do like being called that way. If someone wants you to call it “it”, it's not offensive – it's actually respectful. But remember that it/its pronouns have a history of transphobic use, so only with people who explicitly wish it.
examples: I think it is very nice.
I met it recently.
Is this its dog?
It told me that the house is its.
It said it would rather do it itself.
It is really beautiful.
It answered the phone.
It takes good care of its cat.
It did it all by itself.
It talks in its sleep.
It landed the plane safely.
It argues that…
Did you buy it its gift?
I asked it if I can borrow its pencil.
I talked to it yesterday.
Would you like to go to the movies with it?
Can you call it when its cat awakes?
Its graduation starts soon.
My favorite color is purple, its is yellow.
it.name: it/its

one.history: “One” is used in formal English when talking about a general or a hypothetical person. Recently people started using “one” also as their personal pronoun.
examples: I think one is very nice.
I met one recently.
Is this one's dog?
One told me that the house is one's.
One said one would rather do it oneself.
One is really beautiful.
One answered the phone.
One takes good care of one's cat.
One did it all by oneself.
One talks in one's sleep.
One landed the plane safely.
One argues that…
Did you buy one one's gift?
I asked one if I can borrow one's pencil.
I talked to one yesterday.
Would you like to go to the movies with one?
Can you call one when one's cat awakes?
One's graduation starts soon.
My favorite color is purple, one's is yellow.
one.name: one/one's

ae.history: Created by David Lindsay for a 1920 novel A Voyage to Arcturus, where it's used by an alien, third-sex species.
examples: I think ae is very nice.
I met aer recently.
Is this aer dog?
Ae told me that the house is aers.
Ae said ae would rather do it aerself.
Ae is really beautiful.
Ae answered the phone.
Ae takes good care of aer cat.
Ae did it all by aerself.
Ae talks in aer sleep.
Ae landed the plane safely.
Ae argues that…
Did you buy aer aer gift?
I asked aer if I can borrow aer pencil.
I talked to aer yesterday.
Would you like to go to the movies with aer?
Can you call aer when aer cat awakes?
Aer graduation starts soon.
My favorite color is purple, aers is yellow.
ae.name: ae/aer

co.history: Created by Mary Orovan in 1970, derived from the Indo-European *ko.
examples: I think co is very nice.
I met co recently.
Is this cos dog?
Co told me that the house is co's.
Co said co would rather do it coself.
Co is really beautiful.
Co answered the phone.
Co takes good care of cos cat.
Co did it all by coself.
Co talks in cos sleep.
Co landed the plane safely.
Co argues that…
Did you buy co cos gift?
I asked co if I can borrow cos pencil.
I talked to co yesterday.
Would you like to go to the movies with co?
Can you call co when cos cat awakes?
Cos graduation starts soon.
My favorite color is purple, co's is yellow.
co.name: co/cos

e.history: Coined by Michael Spivak in 1990 for his manual The Joy of TeX to avoid gendering people in the examples.
examples: I think e is very nice.
I met em recently.
Is this eir dog?
E told me that the house is eirs.
E said e would rather do it emself.
E is really beautiful.
E answered the phone.
E takes good care of eir cat.
E did it all by emself.
E talks in eir sleep.
E landed the plane safely.
E argues that…
Did you buy em eir gift?
I asked em if I can borrow eir pencil.
I talked to em yesterday.
Would you like to go to the movies with em?
Can you call em when eir cat awakes?
Eir graduation starts soon.
My favorite color is purple, eirs is yellow.
e.name: e/em/eir

e/em/es.history: First coined by {https://blogs.illinois.edu/view/25/667453458=Francis Augustus Brewsterin in 1841}, but also often credited to {https://medium.com/matthews-place/the-history-of-neopronouns-366b1fee48c4=James Rogers in 1890}. Since then multiple versions were created, differing in declension and capitalisation.
examples: I think e is very nice.
I met em recently.
Is this es dog?
E told me that the house is ems.
E said e would rather do it emself.
E is really beautiful.
E answered the phone.
E takes good care of es cat.
E did it all by emself.
E talks in es sleep.
E landed the plane safely.
E argues that…
Did you buy em es gift?
I asked em if I can borrow es pencil.
I talked to em yesterday.
Would you like to go to the movies with em?
Can you call em when es cat awakes?
Es graduation starts soon.
My favorite color is purple, ems is yellow.
e/em/es.name: e/em/es

ey.history: {https://web.archive.org/web/20211130005355/https://research.cristanwilliams.com/2012/02/24/1975-transgender-cross-gender/=Coined by Christine M. Elverson} in 1975 for a contest to create an alternative to the singular {/they=they}. Those forms are created by dropping “th” from “they”.
examples: I think ey is very nice.
I met em recently.
Is this eir dog?
Ey told me that the house is eirs.
Ey said ey would rather do it emself.
Ey is really beautiful.
Ey answered the phone.
Ey takes good care of eir cat.
Ey did it all by emself.
Ey talks in eir sleep.
Ey landed the plane safely.
Ey argues that…
Did you buy em eir gift?
I asked em if I can borrow eir pencil.
I talked to em yesterday.
Would you like to go to the movies with em?
Can you call em when eir cat awakes?
Eir graduation starts soon.
My favorite color is purple, eirs is yellow.
ey.name: ey/em

I met per recently.

thon.history: Created by Charles Crozat Converse in 1858, thon/thons/thonself is one of the first known examples of creating a gender neutral pronoun. “Thon” is a contraction of “that one”.
examples: I think thon is very nice.
I met thon recently.
Is this thons dog?
Thon told me that the house is thon's.
Thon said thon would rather do it thonself.
Thon is really beautiful.
Thon answered the phone.
Thon takes good care of thons cat.
Thon did it all by thonself.
Thon talks in thons sleep.
Thon landed the plane safely.
Thon argues that…
Did you buy thon thons gift?
I asked thon if I can borrow thons pencil.
I talked to thon yesterday.
Would you like to go to the movies with thon?
Can you call thon when thons cat awakes?
Thons graduation starts soon.
My favorite color is purple, thon's is yellow.
thon.name: thon/thons

ze.history: Hir was first proposed {https://blogs.illinois.edu/view/25/809608=in 1920} in Sacramento Bee. Spelt as hier, it was proposed in {https://public.oed.com/blog/new-words-in-the-oed-march-2019/=1910} in Baltimore Sun.
examples: I think ze is very nice.
I met hir recently.
Is this hir dog?
Ze told me that the house is hirs.
Ze said ze would rather do it hirself.
Ze is really beautiful.
Ze answered the phone.
Ze takes good care of hir cat.
Ze did it all by hirself.
Ze talks in hir sleep.
Ze landed the plane safely.
Ze argues that…
Did you buy hir hir gift?
I asked hir if I can borrow hir pencil.
I talked to hir yesterday.
Would you like to go to the movies with hir?
Can you call hir when hir cat awakes?
Hir graduation starts soon.
My favorite color is purple, hirs is yellow.
ze.name: ze/hir

ze/zir.history: Derived from {ze/hir=ze/hir} {https://public.oed.com/blog/new-words-in-the-oed-march-2019/=in the 1990s}, with a history reaching as far back as {https://blogs.illinois.edu/view/25/705317=1848}. {https://www.pugetsound.edu/sites/default/files/2022-11/history-of-gender-neutral-pronoun.pdf=Coining in 1972}, as ze/zim/zees/zeeself, was based on the German plural 3rd person pronoun sie.
examples: I think ze is very nice.
I met zir recently.
Is this zir dog?
Ze told me that the house is zirs.
Ze said ze would rather do it zirself.
Ze is really beautiful.
Ze answered the phone.
Ze takes good care of zir cat.
Ze did it all by zirself.
Ze talks in zir sleep.
Ze landed the plane safely.
Ze argues that…
Did you buy zir zir gift?
I asked zir if I can borrow zir pencil.
I talked to zir yesterday.
Would you like to go to the movies with zir?
Can you call zir when zir cat awakes?
Zir graduation starts soon.
My favorite color is purple, zirs is yellow.
ze/zir.name: ze/zir

examples: I think zhe is very nice.
I met zher recently.
Is this zher dog?
Zhe told me that the house is zhers.
Zhe said zhe would rather do it zherself.
Zhe is really beautiful.

Zher graduation starts soon.

zhe.name: zhe/zher

ki.history: {https://www.yesmagazine.org/issue/together-earth/2015/03/30/alternative-grammar-a-new-language-of-kinship=Created by Robin Wall Kimmerer} to counteract the objectification of the natural world and to recognise living beings as distinct from inanimate objects (“it”). The pronoun set was {https://karahuntermoon.com/2023/05/19/more-on-ki-and-kin-pronouns/=adjusted by Kara Huntermoon} to make it more consistent with existing English grammar rules.
examples: I think ki is very nice.
I met kin recently.
Is this kins dog?
Ki told me that the house is kins.
Ki said ki would rather do it kinself.
Ki is really beautiful.
Ki answered the phone.
Ki takes good care of kins cat.
Ki did it all by kinself.
Ki talks in kins sleep.
Ki landed the plane safely.
Ki argues that…
Did you buy kin kins gift?
I asked kin if I can borrow kins pencil.
I talked to kin yesterday.
Would you like to go to the movies with kin?
Can you call kin when kins cat awakes?
Kins graduation starts soon.
My favorite color is purple, kins is yellow.
ki.name: ki/kin
